title: 5 new restaurants we’re excited to try in November
author: Jillian Dara
bullets: All'Antico Vinaio opens in Boston's Back Bay with its famous Florentine flatbread sandwiches, including options like La Toscana and L'Inferno.
Capricho Colombian Steakhouse launches in West Roxbury, serving premium grilled meats with Colombian flavors, such as Punta de Anca and Mar y Tierra.
Twisted Fate Brewing debuts its second taproom in Revere, featuring 16 beer taps and an onsite restaurant offering pizza and pretzels.

title: Former Gov. Charlie Baker’s father dies at 97
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Charles D. Baker III, former transportation official and father of ex-Gov. Charlie Baker, died at 97 in Needham.
He was a consultant for U.S. Departments of Defense and Health and Human Services, and taught at Northeastern University.
Baker III was a key adviser to his son, the former governor, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Falcons accused Patriots of illegal simulation of a snap on crucial fourth quarter play
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Falcons accuse Patriots of illegal snap simulation during a crucial play in their 24-23 loss.
Head coach Raheem Morris claims Patriots mimicked Falcons' quarterback clapping, causing an early snap.
Patriots' coach Mike Vrabel dismissed the allegations, jokingly referring to the situation as 'Clapgate.'

title: A Worcester woman has been missing since leaving work Friday morning
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Joanna Brown, 30, disappeared after leaving Bean Counter Bakery Cafe on Grove Street, Worcester around 9 a.m. Friday.
Brown is 5-foot-6 with hazel eyes and may be driving a 2025 Gray Mitsubishi Outlander, plate 5GPN93.
She may be in Holyoke or Springfield; contact Worcester police at 508-799-8606 with any information.

title: ‘Clapgate’: Mike Vrabel responded to Falcons’ accusations of Patriots’ illegal clapping
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Patriots coach Mike Vrabel dismissed Falcons' allegations of illegal clapping during their narrow 24-23 win.
Vrabel praised wide receiver DeMario Douglas for playing despite personal tragedy after his uncle's death.
Patriots, with a 7-2 record, remain active ahead of NFL trade deadline, focused on long-term team building.

title: Lululemon shoplifting spree continues in Boston
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Third shoplifting incident occurred at Lululemon in Boston in just over a month, with ongoing investigations.
Boston police received a report of a larceny in progress at 776 Boylston St. Lululemon on Sunday evening.
Previous incidents involved thefts of $700 and $6,600 in merchandise; no arrests have been made yet.

title: Two Red Sox outfielders earn Gold Glove Awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Wilyer Abreu and Ceddanne Rafaela of the Boston Red Sox win 2025 Rawlings Gold Glove Awards.
Abreu wins the Gold Glove in right field for the second consecutive year despite playing only 115 games.
Rafaela, a first-time winner, leads A.L. centerfielders with 21 Outs Above Average and 19 runs prevented.

title: Middle school principal in Maine draws criticism after dressing as ICE agent for Halloween
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mt. Blue Middle School principal criticized for Halloween costume resembling an ICE agent with a labeled vest and cap.
Superintendent confirms awareness of the incident, stating it occurred off school grounds and is being addressed internally.
Project Relief Maine criticized the costume, highlighting its potential impact on immigrant students' sense of safety.

title: What Christian Gonzalez said about his head injury
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Christian Gonzalez said he was fine after a head injury in the Patriots' game against the Falcons.
Gonzalez cleared concussion protocol but was not needed to return as Patriots controlled the final drive.
The Patriots won by one point, marking their closest victory of the season, after a missed Falcons extra point.

title: South End residents say they picked up 180 needles in less than a week at neighborhood park
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: South End residents collected 180 needles from Southwest Corridor Park in six days, highlighting safety concerns.
The needles were used to create an 'SOS' message to draw attention to drug use in the area.
Boston distributes over 81,000 needles monthly for harm reduction, but residents call for more needle pick-up resources.
